posts.name: David
posts.cooked:
I’m excited to share a project I’ve been working on: an FRC Driver Station app for Android devices .

This app replicates many of the functions of the official FRC Driver Station, allowing teams to practice and experiment more flexibly.

The idea originated from CTRE ’s feature that allows you to set motor speed from your phone. However, for it to function, you must have a Driver Station ( DS ) to enable the robot. I believe this will be very useful for prototyping and testing.

The main screen to control the Robot: Screenshot - Enabled 1408×2974 298 KB

Screenshot - Enabled 1408×2974 298 KB

Screenshot - Enabled 1408×2974 298 KB

The Settings Screen: ScreenShot -  Screen 2 1408×2974 269 KB

ScreenShot -  Screen 2 1408×2974 269 KB

ScreenShot -  Screen 2 1408×2974 269 KB

Overlay: ScreenShot - Overlay 1408×2974 367 KB

ScreenShot - Overlay 1408×2974 367 KB

ScreenShot - Overlay 1408×2974 367 KB

Enable, Disable, and E-Stop functionalities.

Communication status indicator with the RoboRIO.

Ping and diagnostics tools.

Overlay controls to manage your robot even when the app is in the background.

This app is only available for Android devices, and I’m currently not releasing it publicly due to the potential risks associated with its use. However:

Mentors who are interested can DM me, and I will send them the .apk file for testing and use.

WPI developers or “Trusted Mentors” are welcome to DM me as well. I will provide access to the source code to support the development of official tools or just checking it out.

Closed Source : The app’s source code will remain private to ensure responsible usage and to prevent modifications that could make the app unsafe.

Testing Only : Please use this app only for testing and practice purposes in a controlled environment. It is not intended to replace the official Driver Station at events or for critical applications.

If you’re a mentor or WPI developer and are interested in the app, feel free to DM me! I’d love to hear your feedback and suggestions. A Mentor for me is someone that’s inside the Mentor Forum in CD . (or can verify in another way)

The reason behind making it Mentor access only is that I want at least one mentor to know about this feature and will be responsible for it. (The mentor can share the .apk file with his students)

notice.raw: Moderator Note: Using unofficial, unsupported software to control a robot comes with significant, inherent safety risks. Please do your own research and due diligence (in addition to reviewing any concerns outlined in the reply), and consider all potential risks of harm before trying any unsupported software.
notice.cooked: Moderator Note: Using unofficial, unsupported software to control a robot comes with significant, inherent safety risks. Please do your own research and due diligence (in addition to reviewing any concerns outlined in the reply), and consider all potential risks of harm before trying any unsupported software.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: What safety interlocks does this implement? Does it have the watchdog timers the official Driver Station does? Does it run with elevated or real-time priority to ensure other processes on the phone don’t starve it?
I could see use in a similar app that has nothing but a giant E-stop button. Then, anyone, particularly mentors with a sharper eye, could E-stop at will if they see something amiss.

posts.name: David
posts.cooked:
It just sends the “eanble”/“disable”… packet every 20ms.

calcmogul:

Does it run with elevated or real-time priority to ensure other processes on the phone don’t starve it?

I didn’t setup any “elevated or real-time priority” but it did work for me. If you can provide information about “elevated priority”, I would love to hear.

If you have any safety restrictions you believe should be added, let me know.

posts.name: David
posts.cooked: Its a potential use of the app too!

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
DavidMasin:

It just sends the “eanble”/“disable”… packet every 20ms.

Does it verify that it is still receiving packets back in a timely manner?

posts.name: David
posts.cooked: No. What is the reason behind doing it? I just want the robot to be enabled/disabled I shouldn’t really care what it sends back, no?

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: Its controlling a 150 lb machine that has the capability to seriously injure someone. Things responding in a timely manner, and knowing they’re still responsive, are absolutely critical.

posts.name: David
posts.cooked: What information should I get from the Roborio, to make sure “they’re still responsive”? Do you mean just checking “getting something back from the robot”?

posts.name: Graham Howard
posts.cooked: If you don’t know the answer to that, you shouldn’t publish a Driverstation.

posts.name: David
posts.cooked:
First of all, I want to make sure this is safe as possible, that’s why I ask. In addition, it’s not possible to Deploy code to it, it’s not possible to connect controllers to the app, it is meant to be used for Prototypes, and you can’t enable Autonomous mode.

For us its a huge problem each year getting computers to run Krakens/Falcons to see if a prototype works, and made a solution for it. I didnt make it open source and mandated a Mentor to be responsible for this app/feature.

All of the questions I ask is to make it better, if you think its not for your team, its your choice.

Again, if you want to help make it safer I’m welcome to hear suggestions / redirect me to a place where I can learn about it.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
DavidMasin:

For us its a huge problem each year getting computers to run Krakens/Falcons to see if a prototype works

Can you explain why using the official driver station on the same computer where you have Phoenix Tuner X open doesn’t meet your needs?

posts.name: David
posts.cooked:
I have Tuner X open on my phone, thus I dont need a computer.

Configuration utility for CTR Electronics product...

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: Well you need a computer at competitions anyway. I’m not sure how your team runs, but I’m a big fan of testing the exact same way you would be using the robot at a comp (as much as possible), which means using a computer for the DS .

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
This is an interesting idea but the question is if it’s actually possible to implement properly.

What I mean by that is, clearly this is only meant to put the RIO in an enable state for the purpose of using TunerX, alright reasonable goal (though there are a handful of other ways of running motor controllers in prototypes such as the CANIvore or PWM control).

To me what that means is that it should not be possible to enable a real robot running user code. This could easily be catastrophic as maybe someone connects their phone to the wrong SSID somehow and enable untested code on a deathtrap with wheels and no controllers. I think it would probably be fine but you never know and its reasonable to be weary to run anything unofficial in that situation.

Maybe you could have an “official” test image that either it deploys automatically or you require users deploy, and then the app listens for a signal from the RIO verifying that its running this “safe” image.

However after all that, there’s still an open issue of running Tuner X on a full robot (which people do) and not necessarily being able to disable it because the UI thread of the app hangs, or I dont know, the phones touch screen just glitches out.

posts.name: David
posts.cooked:
bathtubed:

To me what that means is that it should not be possible to enable a real robot running user code. This could easily be catastrophic as maybe someone connects their phone to the wrong SSID somehow and enable untested code on a deathtrap with wheels and no controllers. I think it would probably be fine but you never know and its reasonable to be weary to run anything unofficial in that situation.

Maybe you could have an “official” test image that either it deploys automatically or you require users deploy, and then the app listens for a signal from the RIO verifying that its running this “safe” image.

Love the idea, will look into implementing it!

bathtubed:

However after all that, there’s still an open issue of running Tuner X on a full robot (which people do) and not necessarily being able to disable it because the UI thread of the app hangs, or I dont know, the phones touch screen just glitches out.

If you leave the Tuner X app it auto-disables, so even if for some reason my app “glitches”, the Tuner X app will disable the motor.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
DavidMasin:

If you leave the Tuner X app it auto-disables, so even if for some reason my app “glitches”, the Tuner X app will disable the motor.

Yes, but what about the rest of the code on the robot, which is likely also controlling motors?

posts.name: David
posts.cooked:
Do you mean this scenario? You have a code on the robot that’s when enabled on Tele-Operated mode it starts moving motors WITHOUT any controller input (because if you have any controller input, it means you have enabled the Official DS and connected a controller to it)

If thats the case, I would say: Your code is very unsafe becuase it moves a motor uncontrollably and not safe with no controllers connected.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
There could be a command to keep a shooter at speed whenever a game piece is in the conveyor. That wouldn’t require controller input.

DavidMasin:

Your code is very unsafe becuase it moves a motor uncontrollably

Yes, it is controllable. I can disable the robot and I know for a fact the motor would stop.

posts.name: David
posts.cooked:
ajs2:

There could be a command to keep a shooter at speed whenever a game piece is in the conveyor. That wouldn’t require controller input.

I believe if a shooter starts spinning is not not safe. Of course, you don’t want it to happen “unwillingly” but it won’t harm anyone if everyone is in a safe distance while the robot is turned on.

In addition, the idea about it came from us needing the ability to enable/control a motor for a prototype.

It shouldn’t Enable/Disable any “assembled” robot!!
